addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord, the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

7 Decemb
r
1590
M
r
Bodley to my L.

page.lettertext:
fol.15r
May it please yo
r
good L. yesternight the
Generall states sent their Greffier unto me,
w
t
an Answear to her
Ma
tie
in
e maters propo-
sed by
M
r
Wilkes
and me. To
e end that
yo
r
L. might presently have it, I tooke no leasure
to peruse it, but read it over cursory wise, and
caused a copie to be speedely written, whiche I
have joined to this letter: beseeching yo
r
L. to
impart it w
t
her Ma
tie
. I did never yet imagine
that they would frame any answear, to satisfie
her Hig
nes
yet I thought it should have made a more
plausible showe, then their other answears heereto-
fore, to
e self same demaundes. But, to my
understanding, it hath bin apparant of a long
time, that because they have resolved, to governe
all alone, they will seeke indirectly, to frustrat
the Contract, and to free their estate of her Hig
nes
autoritie. By
e date of their Apostilles, it
is 2 monethes agoe, that all was concluded:
w
ch
I knowe not wherupon, they have staied in
their handes. It is saied that their Depu-
tes depart w
t
in these 2 daies: who, as I doe
understand, doe openly refuse to deale in
other causes, then
e mater of trafficke. Ne-
vertheles they have taken a transcript bothe of
o
r
Propositions, and of
e forsaied Apostilles; and
have secret instructions, howe to answear to
any thing, that may be objected. As yet
I have not heard from yo
r
L. what her Ma
tie
doth intend, about
e letters to the Provinces: for
w
ch
, in my opinion, the opportunitie is lost:
But if her Hig
nes
will vouchesafe, to signe that
one for
M
r
Buis
, to
e
states of Utrecht
, it will
fol.15v
stande him presently in steede, and give him cause
to be persuaded, that his honest endevo
rs
are grati-
ously remembred. Ever sins
Count Mau-
rice
missed of his purpose, in
e enterprise of
Dun-
kerke
, we have had in a maner cessation of armes:
e Count being busied in his governments of
Utrecht
and
Overyssell
: where as yet he remaineth.
The Councel of state hath required
e states Ge-
nerall, to move
e Provinces for an extraordinary
Levie of 3000 foote, and 300 horse, to be imploi-
ed in
e filde, for half a yere. What successe it
will have, I can not signifie: but
e assembly of
the states is earnestly bent, to
e furtherance of
it, and have made to
at effect, a remonstrance
to
e Provinces. We are secretly ad-
vertised, and, as it is conceaved, very truly,
at
the Enemie doth provide for
e present surprise
of some speciall place, w
ch
is supposed, (for as yet
we have no certaintie) to be ether
Berghen
, or
Breda
. By reason wherof they have sent
M
r
Gilpin
to Berghen, and an other to Breda, to for-
warne
e Governo
rs
. Howbeit their chiefest feare
is of Berghen: where
e Enemie hath lately
essaied, w
t
promises of great rewardes, to move
the
Lady Morgan
, to persuade w
t
her
husband
, to
revolt. But for
e discharge of their duties,
they have dealt, as it seemeth, very discreetly,
especially
e Governo
r
: of whome, and of all
at
practise of
e Enemie, and also of that, whiche
hath passed about it, in
e Councel of state, I will
write yo
r
L. in my next. It is
advertised from
Bruxells
, that
e
D. of Parma
doth assemble
e states of those contreis, as it is
fol.16r
thought, in
Andwerp
, and for a newe contri-
bution: as w
t
all it is signified, that there
will be at
at Assembly, two Deputies from
e
Em-
pero
r
, w
t
commission to propose unto them, and
w
t
them, a general peace to
e united Provinces
The bruite that is abroade of this Proposition,
the soddaine returne of
e D. of Parma, and
e
Liguers
desire to come to agreement (for so it
is reported)
that
doth putte many men in
belief, that
King Philip
is dead. Whiche is the
effect of as muche, as I can signifie at this p
n
t:
for w
ch
I take my humble leave.
From
e
Hage
. De
c
7 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
